caption: First things first, to enter, you descend a long set of stairs, so inaccessible to wheelchairs.  Next, at 15 euros when I visited, it's a pretty steep entry fee for what you get.  And a warning: the place is very much aimed at small children, so if you're not one of those or a parent of one, or a serious connoisseur of magic and magic history, you may find it a bit of a tourist trap.  My first impression was it had fantastic ambience with low light (I'm light-sensitive) and cave-like ambience as it's in a former basement.  On arrival, depending on the schedule, you're invited to a magic show in a little theater. While conducted in French, I understood enough to enjoy. The tricks and illusions were on the basic side, so if you are a magic connoisseur, you might not be taken with them, but I found them--and the magician--very entertaining.  Once the show's over, they funnel you into the heart of the museum, which has a number of genuinely fascinating pieces. The optical illusions were a highlight. Though once you've taken those in, which takes, at most, half an hour, that's kind of it. Being near-sighted, I didn't even bother reading most of the signs, so that probably detracted from my experience.  The other half of the museum is the automotons. For those who don't know, these are little doll-like figures constructed to repetitively perform entertaining tasks when you press a button. Some were very cool while others I've completely forgotten about. In total, they take up about two and a half rooms.  And that's it! One big room full of artifacts and interactive optical illusions and another couple of rooms full of push-button performers.  One final warning: some of the pieces, especially the older posters, lean toward the culturally insensitive, so if you're not into that, maybe avoid.  Overall, it was a fun hour of exploration, so if you're looking for something for the kids, it's cheaper and closer than Disneyland, but you will run out of things to do before you know it. Without the very friendly and helpful staff, it would've been three stars.

This is a great museum for kids and lovers of magic. The automatic part of the museum really wasn't that amazing. I was hoping for more creepy dolls, most of the artefacts were kinda dull. Kids would enjoy the "pushing buttons" factor. The magic museum side was pretty cool. Live magic and some nice interactive displays. There was a bunch of kids having a birthday party so was filled with laughter. I imagine when empty this place is creepy as.

If you fancy a cozy underground cellar-looking apartment full of poorly maintained memorabilia from magic shows of the early and mid 1900’s you will not be disappointed. If you expect anything modern or well-made, to show you some spectacular magic, will will have wasted your money, like we did. (And by the way it costs quite a bit of money)

Always on the lookout for offbeat places, this (and the attached Musée des Automates) fits the bill. You start off by looking at an extensive collection of "Automates", which are weird and fun. Then, all of a sudden, you'll be herded over to the "Magie" section for a show! We were fortunate to be there on a day a class of 4-year olds were there, and it was priceless! (Without the children, your mileage may vary)  It may not be everyone's cup of Oolong, but we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.

Such an interesting little place - great fun for kids and adults.  We arrived near closing time, but they put on a short magic show just for us.  You won't need more than hour or two, but a welcome change from the mega-museums of Paris, and unlikely to be crowded.

Ver cool small cute museum with interesting items. The magic show was hilarious! After the show there was an informative commentary about the history of magic. I learned a lot and had a lot of fun. Perfect for children but also for adults with a sense of humour.
This place was brilliant. Interesting automata, a decently performed magic show and optical illusions and props. Great value, would highly recommend a visit if in Paris.

The place is not big, but it has a collection of very old automated toys that the visitors can activate one by one with the press of a button. There is a magic show for children to enjoy during the visit. The museum also has a section dedicated to illusions and old cinematographic magic tricks.
The painting with the hands scared me! The magic show was really cool, the magician is a true mind reader. Great way to spend an hour.

A really nice place to visit honestly! It’s a little small for the price, but I think it’s pretty worth it. The underground area is just stunning, it looks like an old wine cave from the South of France. The expos are fun and interactive, and you end up learning a lot.  Kids will be happy to press all the buttons, teens will have fun at the “will you dare put your hands in this” section, and for adults well honestly magic is always fun to watch.  Our tour guide was hilarious and very knowledgeable, it was a blast. And the magician was so good, honestly he did basic tricks but damn I couldn’t figure a single one out. He interacted a bunch with the audience and blew our minds with cool tricks and funny comments.  I recommend!

What a nice surprise! Our 7 yo boy was there for the Workshop and we joined in afterwards. The magician show was really so good and very entertaining. The introduction afterwords to the actual museum was professional and the guide was lovely with the kids. It was very interesting and the kids and adults loved it. Highly recommend!

The magic show is good and the museum has a cool spooky atmosphere and some interesting items. But a lot of the things are broken - you press the button and nothing happens. And it's not cheap to go in but then there are several machines that are coin operated too! They should give you a couple of little discs with your ticket to work those.
This is so much fun. Bring your kids and go!
I like the museum, but it's more for kids than for adults. Apart from that, the museum would benefit a lot if everything gets translated to English.

I had high expectations and I was disappointed untill the show started. I rarely get excited, however, the show was amazing, we were just 4-5 spectators which made it much better as the magician interacted with all of us. Also if you say that you don't speak French the magician also speaks English which was very convenient. It's worth it only if you go to the show!
What can I say? One of my favorite places in Paris. I don't care if I have been a million times I always visit and support them for what they do. A great staff.
Our son picked this stop on or day out around Paris, what a great place!! Interesting antique magic items and a live magic show included with entry. Whole family enjoyed!

An unexpected delightful experience! The museum is small, but people working there are passionate about the world and the history of magic. They gave us a detailed tour of the museum and shared with us some of the magic of the place.  There is also a beautiful collection of automates! We also attended a magic show that delighted and amused both kids and adults!
Depends perhaps little person for person. Its not bad, for me it was nothing super great, except the small live magic show, its always so amazing to see very near live magic tricks.

It tells the history of magic, with pictures, text and some interactive items (automats). It is mainly in French. They have a short magic presentation every 20min, which is great, but it could be more ludic for the kids. In general I would suggest to go there if you don't want to stay home in a rainy day.

It appears to be a private museum.  There are some interesting things, but it is very small.  There is a small show with a magician and the staff tells some stories, but everything is only in French.  The visit is not worth the money for the ticket.  I do not recommend visiting for people who do not know French.

A gem of a place. We were lucky enough to be there when a magic show was underway; just right for kids and we adults thoroughly enjoyed it. The mechanical toys were wonderful, especially since you could animate them by pushing a button -usually, these days, you just get to watch a little video of something like that while viewing the doll/mannequin/etc. just displayed.  It was really fun.

A small and unusual museum of all things magic. The magic show was fun with a participant from the audience. There was a hands on animatronics section with buttons to push. The children there seemed to like this. There were displays like you would see at the circus with the funny mirrors. Lots of hands on interaction. Great for kids and adults.

Interactive automatons that please young and old alike, a live magic show featuring a professional magician, an elegant magic shop, funny tour guide, amazing relics from magic's history, and all in a cellar beneath the street in Paris. Highly recommended for families.

A really fun little gem of a museum. They have an amazing collection of historic animatronics that I imagine would have been very magical in their day. It was delightful. They also had a funny, multi-lingual magician who wowed my boys are ensured there was full audience participation and attention. We laughed and were amazed with his tricks. The older man who seemed to run the place didn't speak english, but still went out of his way to interact with the children and delight them will paper helicopters. Very much recommended activity if you have children!

This is a must to visit in Paris...as important as the Eiffel Tower due to the historical significance and passion of its creator. A marvelous collection and representation of so many artists,illusionists and Wizards that were the initial inventors of the world in which we live today! I was invited by Gaetan Bloom and Georges Proust to experience a moment suspended in time! ....to be followed!

Went today with my two eleven-years olds and their grandmother - we all really enjoyed it - the sixteenth century underground cellar lends a lot of ambiance with its labyrinth of rooms and vaulted stone doorways; the magic show was entertaining; there was a lot of history contained in the exhibitions; and we were fascinated by the displays of optical illusions and old automats.There is also a small shop for budding amateur magicians - I bought a trick and the magician kindly offered to help us out in the future if we get stuck. Only recommendation - give some dates of some exhibits and put some information in English as everything was in French. Overall - definitely recommend it if interested in the history of magic.
A very charmante, intimate and personal museum with friendly staff. We have even received a magic show and they also offered a tour to tell us more about the items. Can recommend for young and old!
Amazing show. Graciously, they try to speak English and it's enough to understand and have a great time with. I really loved this show and will suggest it to any traveler.
Great place for kids age 4+! Fun with interactive exhibits and great for kids imagination. Good magic show even if you don't speak french. Cool historical paraphernalia.

First, I will tell you that we did not actually visit the museum, but when I paid with two credit cards, both cards did not work. I was able to withdraw cash from the card with no problem, so basically they try to make you pay with cash. A rip-off! DO NOT GO THERE.

The place is nice but not very informative. The exposition of automatic machines is quite interestong, even though some of them are broken. We really enjoyed the show, it was entertaining but please note that it is entirely in French and no translation to English is available.
Very nice small museum for kids, with a magician performing every 20 minutes or so. many mirrors and old automats. you can buy some tricks in the museum shop

Underwhelming on all levels. Exhibits are shabby and hardly remarkable. A bunch of rundown automats and a vanilla, short magic show. Depressing interiors overall. Way overprized, 14 euro for adults, 10 for kids. Not worth it at all.
They possessed deep history of magician and their mind tricks. However don’t put much expectations to see the tricks in the museum.
M’amuser beaucoup. Très bonne musée. The magic show is so accessible even for a foreigner who doesn’t understand French very well can enjoy.

Very disappointing. Many of the demonstration buttons do not work. However, there is a large collection of artifacts. Most of the displays do look like miniatures. The staff is friendly and there is a magic show for all to watch
A quirky museum showcasing props, posters, and optical illusions from mostly 19th century illusionists. Close-up magic show that was impressive and bilingual! Reminded me of “Hugo Cabret”.
